Kushiwakamaru Review | Bon Appetit

And plenty of beer, too.FacebookPinterestTwitterEmailKee Byung-keunGO HERE: for a no-frills yakitori dinner. A lot of people in Tokyo will often say that simple is best, and this is never more true than when eating out. Kushiwakamaru is all golden oldies: all of your favorite chicken parts flavored by little more than salt, sauce, and smoke. Portions are generous and ordering half the menu is a common temptation. When you wash it all down with an unnecessarily large glass of beer, you have what a huge percentage of salarymen spend their office hours dreaming about.ORDER THE: favorites, like wings, skin, and hearts. The standouts are the tsukune (chicken meatballs), tanuki (a stuffed shiitake mushroom), and the chizu-pi (a green pepper stuffed with cheese and wrapped in bacon, like a Japanese jalapeño popper). Before you pump the brakes, order the dashaku-imo, a whole potato from Hokkaido that has been cooked over the coals and crowned with a big wedge of butter. Finish your meal with a stiff lemon sour and a bowl of rice topped with salmon roe.THE VIBE IS: an old-school affair—warm, smoky, and unpretentious. It‘s almost always crowded and conversations can get raucous when fueled by so much good food and alcohol.PRACTICAL STUFF: Open daily from 5 p.m. to midnight. The menu is available in English and the staff speaks some English. Reservations are recommended but not necessary.
